elements.content: Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries possess many practical challenges including the lithium polysulfide (LiPS) “shuttle effect” and their sluggish conversion kinetics. To address these issues, a unique hierarchical porous architecture, combining highly conductive ordered macroporous skeleton and embedded microporous particles is rationally designed as a dual-effective polysulfide immobilizer and conversion promoter. In this nanoporous architecture, Al-doped ZnO (AZO) acts as a conductive macroporous framework, profiting chemical anchoring of LiPS as well as facilitating electrolyte infiltration and ion diffusion; Co nanoparticle-anchored N-doped carbon (Co-NC) derived from CoZn-metal–organic framework is embedded in the macropores to further strengthen the LiPS adsorption, catalytically accelerating conversion kinetics of LiPS simultaneously. Consequently, the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode delivers a notable rate capability of 635.5 mA h g–1 at 5 C. A high area capacity of about 5.8 mA h cm–2 with a mass loading of 6.8 mg cm–2 is also achieved under a lean electrolyte (E/S = 5.7). Additionally, the Li–S pouch cells equipped with Co-NC@AZO can be extended to sulfur loading as high as 4.0 mg cm–2, delivering a superb capability of 897.5 mA h g–1 after 100 cycles. This work puts forward a design for stably cycled and practically viable Li–S batteries.

elements.content: Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries, with a high theoretical energy density (2600 W h kg–1), have received tremendous interest as one of the holy grails in future energy-storage devices. Moreover, the low cost and ecofriendly feature of sulfur, with a theoretical capacity of 1675 mA h g–1, is particularly conducive to their widescale applications. Despite these advantages, the commercial viability of Li–S batteries is still hindered by some technical imperfections, such as low electrical conductivity of sulfur and the discharged products (Li2S2 and Li2S), the solubility of lithium polysulfides (LiPS) in electrolytes, and the subsequent “shuttle effect”, as well as the sluggish kinetics for LiPS conversion reactions. All of these drawbacks can result in a severe capacity decay and poor rate capability of Li–S batteries together with the incomplete utilization of sulfur.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, with a high theoretical energy density (2600 W h kg-1), have received tremendous interest as one of the holy grails in future energy-storage devices. Moreover, the low cost and ecofriendly feature of sulfur, with a theoretical capacity of 1675 mA h g-1, is particularly conducive to their widescale applications. Despite these advantages, the commercial viability of Li-S batteries is still hindered by some technical imperfections, such as low electrical conductivity of sulfur and the discharged products (Li2S2 and Li2S), the solubility of lithium polysulfides (LiPS) in electrolytes, and the subsequent "shuttle effect", as well as the sluggish kinetics for LiPS conversion reactions. All of these drawbacks can result in a severe capacity decay and poor rate capability of Li-S batteries together with the incomplete utilization of sulfur.

elements.content: To resolve the aforementioned challenges, extensive efforts have been made toward the design of multifarious architectures along with functions of the Li–S cell configuration, including the sulfur cathodes, electrolytes, separators, interlayers, and Li anodes. Up to now, numerous sulfur-based electrodes have been developed and reported to mitigate the LiPS shuttling and enhance their redox kinetics. Among all these attempts, porous conductive carbonaceous host materials (carbon nanotubes, carbon hollow spheres, graphene, etc.) have been well studied. In recent years, heteroatoms (N, S, B, O, and P), as well as metal/transition-metal compounds [SnO2, ZnS, CoP, and metal–organic framework (MOF)] with inherent polarity and even catalytic property were introduced to address the LiPS “shuttle effect” and promote polysulfide transformations. In general, strategies to construct effective sulfur cathodes rely mostly on the following: (i) highly conductive materials should be involved to compensate the insulativity of sulfur and its lithiation products, thus facilitating the transport of electron and reducing the ohmic polarization of the battery; (ii) polar materials are crucial for anchoring polysulfide via polar–polar chemical interactions; (iii) catalysts that can promote the transformation of LiPS should be paid more attention; (iv) a well-designed porous structure is beneficial to physical sulfur wrapping, simultaneously moderating the volume expansion of sulfur in the charge and discharge process. To achieve these points, metal sulfide/oxides are often combined with porous carbon scaffolds, or dopants are applied to generate dipoles, yielding a composite that is both conductive and polar in nature. Note that in these cases, porous carbon is usually the host material, whereas metal compounds often act as the supporting material. The relatively “soft” carbon body may face the problem of structural collapse during a long-term charging and discharging process. Considering this, the use of metal compounds, especially metal oxides, as porous host materials will be beneficial to improve the structural stability of the cathode. However, metal oxides generally exhibit low electrical conductivity, limiting their use as cathode hosts. Therefore, the development of porous metal oxide host materials with high conductivity is of great interest.

Note that in these cases, porous carbon is usually the host material, whereas metal compounds often act as the supporting material. elements.content: Herein, a highly conductive and polar three-dimensional ordered macroporous (3DOM) framework was developed by Al-doped ZnO (AZO), a commonly used conductive oxide in photovoltaics. The inherent polarity of 3DOM AZO can provide strengthened LiPS adsorption. In addition, the high conductivity and ordered macropores can efficiently accelerate charge transportation and transfer, electrolyte infiltration, and ion diffusion. To further boost the surface area and corresponding reaction sites, microporous Co-decorated N-doped carbon (Co-NC), derived from the carbonization of the CoZn-MOF, was introduced within the macropores of 3DOM AZO, forming a novel hierarchical porous structure. The microporous Co-NC provides plentiful and accessible active sites of Co nanoparticles as well as N-doped carbon for strong LiPS adsorption and its effective catalytic conversion during charge/discharge cycling, ensuring a high utilization rate of sulfur in lean electrolyte conditions. Combined with these merits, the CoZn-NC@AZO/S cathode exhibits superb cycling stability over 500 cycles at 1 C with a low capacity fading rate of 0.020% per cycle and a high capacity of 635.5 mA h g–1 at 5 C. Furthermore, a high area capacity of 5.8 mA h cm–2 with a sulfur loading of 6.8 mg cm–2 is also achieved at a low electrolyte-to-sulfur ratio (E/S = 5.7). More importantly, the multifunctional CoZn-NC@AZO cathode also shows excellent electrochemical performance in a pouch cell. A high capacity of 897.5 mA h g–1 can be obtained even after 100 cycles at 0.1 C under a sulfur loading of 4.0 mg cm–2 and E/S ratio of 5.2 μL mg–1. Also, the excellent flexibility of the pouch cell is displayed under flat and bending states. This study proposes a novel design strategy for advanced and practicable Li–S batteries.

elements.content: First, polystyrene (PS) spheres 290 nm in diameter were prepared as a macroporous template according to the literature. For generating ZnO, Zn­(NO3)3·6H2O (2.2 g) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL) with continuous stirring. After that, citric acid (0.6 g) was added as a chelating agent to the above solution and uninterruptedly stirred for 30 min. Then, PS spheres (2.0 g) were dipped in the above metal precursor solution and allowed to stand for 4 h. Subsequently, the suspension was filtered by vacuum filtration to remove the excess solution. Following vacuum drying at 60 °C, the dried sample was thermally treated in a tube furnace at 300 °C in Ar for 60 min following ramping at a rate of 1 °C min–1. Then, the temperature was raised again to 500 °C and maintained for 2 h under Ar at a ramping rate of 1 °C min–1. Finally, the ZnO powder was cooled to room temperature and collected. The AZO powder was synthesized by the same method with the addition of a certain amount of Al­(NO3)3·9H2O.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Material Synthesis of ZnO and AZO

First, polystyrene (PS) spheres 290 nm in diameter were prepared as a macroporous template according to the literature. For generating ZnO, Zn(NO3)3⋅6H2O (2.2 g) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL) with continuous stirring. After that, citric acid (0.6 g) was added as a chelating agent to the above solution and uninterruptedly stirred for 30 min. Then, PS spheres (2.0 g) were dipped in the above metal precursor solution and allowed to stand for 4 h. Subsequently, the suspension was filtered by vacuum filtration to remove the excess solution. Following vacuum drying at 60 °C, the dried sample was thermally treated in a tube furnace at 300 °C in Ar for 60 min following ramping at a rate of 1 °C min-1. Then, the temperature was raised again to 500 °C and maintained for 2 h under Ar at a ramping rate of 1 °C min-1. Finally, the ZnO powder was cooled to room temperature and collected. The AZO powder was synthesized by the same method with the addition of a certain amount of Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O.

elements.content: The preparation of ZIF-8 involved methanol solution (50 mL), Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.4 g), and 2-MeIM (4.4 g), followed by stirring and mixing at 25 °C for 8 h. The stirred suspension was then centrifugated and washed thoroughly with methanol and double deionized (DDI) water to remove excess 2-MeIM and dried at 60 °C for 12 h to acquire white ZIF-8 samples. ZIF-8@AZO was prepared by adding AZO powders into the same precursor solution of ZIF-8 and stirring the mixture for 12 h. Finally, the suspension was centrifuged and rinsed with methanol and DDI water and then dried at 60 °C to acquire the ZIF-8@AZO samples.
elements.clean_text:
Material Synthesis of ZIF-8 and ZIF-8@AZO

The preparation of ZIF-8 involved methanol solution (50 mL), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.4 g), and 2-MeIM (4.4 g), followed by stirring and mixing at 25 °C for 8 h. The stirred suspension was then centrifugated and washed thoroughly with methanol and double deionized (DDI) water to remove excess 2-MeIM and dried at 60 °C for 12 h to acquire white ZIF-8 samples. ZIF-8@AZO was prepared by adding AZO powders into the same precursor solution of ZIF-8 and stirring the mixture for 12 h. Finally, the suspension was centrifuged and rinsed with methanol and DDI water and then dried at 60 °C to acquire the ZIF-8@AZO samples.

elements.content: Co­(NO3)2·6H2O with different amounts (e.g., 0.35, 0.70, and 1.40 mmol) was added into DDI (20 mL) water with constant stirring to obtain the Co2+ solution. The final product of Co-NC@AZO was prepared by holding CoZn-MOF@AZO at 300 °C for 1 h and then at 600 °C (or 400 or 800 °C) for 1 h in Ar at a heating rate of 1 °C min–1.
elements.clean_text:
Material Synthesis of CoZn-MOF@AZO and Co-NC@AZO

Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O with different amounts (e.g., 0.35, 0.70, and 1.40 mmol) was added into DDI (20 mL) water with constant stirring to obtain the Co2+ solution. The final product of Co-NC@AZO was prepared by holding CoZn-MOF@AZO at 300 °C for 1 h and then at 600 °C (or 400 or 800 °C) for 1 h in Ar at a heating rate of 1 °C min-1.

elements.content: The Co-NC@AZO (ZIF-8@AZO or AZO) sample and sulfur were mixed homogeneously at a weight ratio of 1:3. After that, the well-mixed material was placed in a reaction kettle which was operated in an Ar-filled glovebox to remove the air and finally heated at 155 °C for a certain time to get the Co-NC@AZO/S (ZIF-8@AZO/S or AZO/S) composite.
elements.clean_text:
Material Synthesis of Co-NC@AZO/S, ZIF-8@AZO/S, and AZO/S

The Co-NC@AZO (ZIF-8@AZO or AZO) sample and sulfur were mixed homogeneously at a weight ratio of 1:3. After that, the well-mixed material was placed in a reaction kettle which was operated in an Ar-filled glovebox to remove the air and finally heated at 155 °C for a certain time to get the Co-NC@AZO/S (ZIF-8@AZO/S or AZO/S) composite.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were tested by a Bruker D8 Discover with monochromatic Cu Kα radiation (the value of λ is 1.5418 Å). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEM2010F) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Hitachi, S-4800) were used for observing the structure as well as the morphology of the samples. The chemical bond information of the materials was gained by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement (K-Alpha XPS). The sample surface area was determined by the surface area and pore distribution analyzer of the V-Sorb 2800P type with calculation by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on SDT Q600 (TA Instruments) at a ramping rate of 6 °C min–1 in N2. Raman spectra were taken using an XploRA Raman instrument with 532 nm excitation. Four-point probe (RH-2035) measurement was used to test the conductivity of the sample. The ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectra were measured by a Cary 60 UV–vis spectrophotometer in the wavelength range of 200 to 800 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Material Characterization

X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were tested by a Bruker D8 Discover with monochromatic Cu Kα radiation (the value of λ is 1.5418 Å). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEM2010F) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Hitachi, S-4800) were used for observing the structure as well as the morphology of the samples. The chemical bond information of the materials was gained by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement (K-Alpha XPS). The sample surface area was determined by the surface area and pore distribution analyzer of the V-Sorb 2800P type with calculation by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on SDT Q600 (TA Instruments) at a ramping rate of 6 °C min-1 in N2. Raman spectra were taken using an XploRA Raman instrument with 532 nm excitation. Four-point probe (RH-2035) measurement was used to test the conductivity of the sample. The ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectra were measured by a Cary 60 UV-vis spectrophotometer in the wavelength range of 200 to 800 nm.

elements.content: The well-mixed sulfur composite, polyvinylidene fluoride, and Super P were combined in a ratio of 8:1:1 by mass; N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone was added dropwise to form a thoroughly blended slurry. The electrodes were built by coating the slurry on an Al foil with a loading mass around 1.5 mg cm–2, and the E/S was 12.0 μL mg–1. In addition, a higher sulfur loading of 6.8 mg cm–2 and a low E/S of 5.7 μL mg–1 were studied for the batteries. The lithium foil was applied as the anode, while Celgard 2500 acted as the separator for battery assembly. The electrolyte was prepared by adding well-dissolved lithium bis (trifluoromethanesulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) (1.0 M) into a mixture of 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) (v/v = 1:1) with LiNO3 (0.2 M). Galvanostatic cycling and rate tests were conducted on a Neware battery test station. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves under 1.7–2.8 V operating potentials were collected by VersaSTAT 4, and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) plots were also obtained from VersaSTAT 4 in a frequency range from 0.01 to 105 Hz.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Measurements

The well-mixed sulfur composite, polyvinylidene fluoride, and Super P were combined in a ratio of 8:1:1 by mass; N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone was added dropwise to form a thoroughly blended slurry. The electrodes were built by coating the slurry on an Al foil with a loading mass around 1.5 mg cm-2, and the E/S was 12.0 μL mg-1. In addition, a higher sulfur loading of 6.8 mg cm-2 and a low E/S of 5.7 μL mg-1 were studied for the batteries. The lithium foil was applied as the anode, while Celgard 2500 acted as the separator for battery assembly. The electrolyte was prepared by adding well-dissolved lithium bis (trifluoromethanesulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) (1.0 M) into a mixture of 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) (v/v = 1:1) with LiNO3 (0.2 M). Galvanostatic cycling and rate tests were conducted on a Neware battery test station. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves under 1.7-2.8 V operating potentials were collected by VersaSTAT 4, and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) plots were also obtained from VersaSTAT 4 in a frequency range from 0.01 to 105 Hz.

elements.content: The soft-packaged Li–S cells were fabricated with the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode, Celgard 2500 separator, and Li foil anode under the same condition as that of the coin cells inside a glovebox. The sulfur cathodes and Li foil anodes were both of size 3 cm × 4 cm. Then, the aluminum and nickel strips were attached to the sides of the cathode and anode as electrode plates, respectively. Finally, the cell was encapsulated with an aluminum/polymer flexible packaging seal.
elements.clean_text:
Assembly of Flexible Li-S Pouch Cells

The soft-packaged Li-S cells were fabricated with the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode, Celgard 2500 separator, and Li foil anode under the same condition as that of the coin cells inside a glovebox. The sulfur cathodes and Li foil anodes were both of size 3 cm × 4 cm. Then, the aluminum and nickel strips were attached to the sides of the cathode and anode as electrode plates, respectively. Finally, the cell was encapsulated with an aluminum/polymer flexible packaging seal.

elements.content: The Li2S6 electrolyte was synthesized via dissolving sulfur and Li2S at a molar ratio of 1:5 in DME/DOL (1:1 v/v) solvent with stirring at 60 °C for 24 h. Symmetric coin cells (2032-type) were assembled with the Co-NC@AZO cathode, Li foil anode, and the same separator. CV tests were performed at 5 mV s–1 using a VersaSTAT 4 workstation, and EIS was measured over a frequency range from 0.01 Hz to 100 kHz.
elements.clean_text:
Symmetric Cell Assembly

The Li2S6 electrolyte was synthesized via dissolving sulfur and Li2S at a molar ratio of 1:5 in DME/DOL (1:1 v/v) solvent with stirring at 60 °C for 24 h. Symmetric coin cells (2032-type) were assembled with the Co-NC@AZO cathode, Li foil anode, and the same separator. CV tests were performed at 5 mV s-1 using a VersaSTAT 4 workstation, and EIS was measured over a frequency range from 0.01 Hz to 100 kHz.

elements.content: The Li2S8 solution was synthesized via mixing Li2S and S at a molar ratio of 1:7 in a solution of tetraglyme and LiTFSI (1 M) and then was stirred continuously at 60 °C for 24 h. The cell was discharged to 2.06 V under a continuous current of 0.112 mA and then kept at a constant voltage of 2.05 V until the current dropped below 0.1 mA.
elements.clean_text:
Li2S Nucleation Characterizations

The Li2S8 solution was synthesized via mixing Li2S and S at a molar ratio of 1:7 in a solution of tetraglyme and LiTFSI (1 M) and then was stirred continuously at 60 °C for 24 h. The cell was discharged to 2.06 V under a continuous current of 0.112 mA and then kept at a constant voltage of 2.05 V until the current dropped below 0.1 mA.

elements.content: The redox behavior of LiPS was investigated by the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) technique in Li2S/methanol (0.1 M) in a three-electrode configuration. The overpotential and the current response from the LSV experiment were used to plot the Tafel curve.
elements.clean_text:
Linear Sweep Voltammetry Measurement

The redox behavior of LiPS was investigated by the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) technique in Li2S/methanol (0.1 M) in a three-electrode configuration. The overpotential and the current response from the LSV experiment were used to plot the Tafel curve.

elements.content: The Li2S6 solution (10 mM) was synthesized via mixing sulfur and Li2S (5:1 in molar ratio) in a solvent mixture of DOL/DME (v/v = 1:1) and stirring vigorously at 60 °C for 24 h in a glovebox. Equal amounts of Co-NC@AZO, ZIF-8@AZO, and AZO powder were added to the Li2S6 solution in the glovebox for adsorption measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Test of LiPS

The Li2S6 solution (10 mM) was synthesized via mixing sulfur and Li2S (5:1 in molar ratio) in a solvent mixture of DOL/DME (v/v = 1:1) and stirring vigorously at 60 °C for 24 h in a glovebox. Equal amounts of Co-NC@AZO, ZIF-8@AZO, and AZO powder were added to the Li2S6 solution in the glovebox for adsorption measurements.

elements.content: Vienna ab initio simulation package program was applied to perform the density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof function was accustomed to explaining the exchange–correlation functional. Li2S2 and Li2S6 were selected as typical LiPS models, and their absorption on AZO (1 0 0) surfaces was studied. Besides, the decomposition barrier for Li2S was determined by a climbing image-nudged elastic band, and the cutoff energy was set as 400 eV. A 2 × 2 × 1 Monkhorst–Pack k-point mesh was applied to the sample for the Brillouin zone. A (3 × 2) unit cell was used for the AZO (1 0 0) surface, while a (2 × 2) unit cell was used for the Co (1 1 1) surface. The vacuum layer space was set as 15 Å. The bottom two-layer atoms were fixed, whereas the remaining atoms and the adsorbates were relaxed fully. The Li2S n (n = 2, 6) adhesion binding energy (E ab) was calculated as follows: E ab = E Li2Sn/slab – E Li2Sn – E slab, where E Li2Sn/slab is the total energy of the absorbed system, E Li2Sn is the energy of the optimized LiPS species, and E slab is the optimized bare surface energy.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Calculation

Vienna ab initio simulation package program was applied to perform the density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof function was accustomed to explaining the exchange-correlation functional. Li2S2 and Li2S6 were selected as typical LiPS models, and their absorption on AZO (1 0 0) surfaces was studied. Besides, the decomposition barrier for Li2S was determined by a climbing image-nudged elastic band, and the cutoff energy was set as 400 eV. A 2 × 2 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh was applied to the sample for the Brillouin zone. A (3 × 2) unit cell was used for the AZO (1 0 0) surface, while a (2 × 2) unit cell was used for the Co (1 1 1) surface. The vacuum layer space was set as 15 Å. The bottom two-layer atoms were fixed, whereas the remaining atoms and the adsorbates were relaxed fully. The Li2S n  (n = 2, 6) adhesion binding energy (E ab) was calculated as follows: E ab = E Li2Sn/slab - E Li2Sn - E slab, where E Li2Sn/slab is the total energy of the absorbed system, E Li2Sn is the energy of the optimized LiPS species, and E slab is the optimized bare surface energy.

elements.content: displays the architecture design of Co-NC@AZO and its functional engineering as a high-performance sulfur cathode. In brief, the synthesis started from the development of the AZO framework by the impregnation of the Al–Zn precursor into self-assembling PS templates, followed by a calcination process (Figure S1). The SEM result in Figure S2 clearly reveals the size uniform morphology of the PS spheres with a diameter of about 290 nm. During the pyrolysis process, the aluminum nitrate and zinc nitrate precursors immersed in the voids of PS spheres tended to crystallize. Meanwhile, the PS templates were gradually decomposed, forming an interconnected macroporous structure to form the 3DOM AZO (AZO). Afterward, by mixing AZO with a solution of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O and 2-MeIM for 12 h, ZIF-8 crystals were formed and randomly embedded in the 3DOM macropores, resulting in the formation of 3DOM ZIF-8@AZO (ZIF-8@AZO). Thereafter, 3DOM CoZn-MOF@AZO (CoZn-MOF@AZO) was prepared by partially replacing the Zn2+ in ZIF-8@AZO by additionally adding Co2+. Finally, Co-NC@AZO was obtained by the high-temperature calcination of CoZn-MOF@AZO under an Ar atmosphere, with Zn atoms in CoZn-MOF removed at the same time.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

  displays the architecture design of Co-NC@AZO and its functional engineering as a high-performance sulfur cathode. In brief, the synthesis started from the development of the AZO framework by the impregnation of the Al-Zn precursor into self-assembling PS templates, followed by a calcination process (Figure S1). The SEM result in Figure S2 clearly reveals the size uniform morphology of the PS spheres with a diameter of about 290 nm. During the pyrolysis process, the aluminum nitrate and zinc nitrate precursors immersed in the voids of PS spheres tended to crystallize. Meanwhile, the PS templates were gradually decomposed, forming an interconnected macroporous structure to form the 3DOM AZO (AZO). Afterward, by mixing AZO with a solution of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 2-MeIM for 12 h, ZIF-8 crystals were formed and randomly embedded in the 3DOM macropores, resulting in the formation of 3DOM ZIF-8@AZO (ZIF-8@AZO). Thereafter, 3DOM CoZn-MOF@AZO (CoZn-MOF@AZO) was prepared by partially replacing the Zn2+ in ZIF-8@AZO by additionally adding Co2+. Finally, Co-NC@AZO was obtained by the high-temperature calcination of CoZn-MOF@AZO under an Ar atmosphere, with Zn atoms in CoZn-MOF removed at the same time.

elements.content: a displays the SEM image of the AZO framework, which confirms the uniform and periodic macropores. Interestingly, the diameter of AZO macropores is measured to be about 200 nm, which is reduced by 31% as compared with that of PS templates due to the shrinkage of the precursor mixture in the calcination process. Moreover, the ZIF-8@AZO displays small ZIF-8 nanoparticles with a size of about 64 nm, which are densely distributed in the pores and on the surface of the AZO framework (b). After calcination treatment, the morphology of the resulting Co-NC@AZO was also examined, indicating almost unchanged morphology of the 3DOM structure and partially decomposed ZIF-8 nanoparticles (c). The TEM image of Co-NC@AZO confirms that the Co-NC nanoparticles with an average particle size of 36.40 nm were casually dispersed on the 3DOM framework (d and S4). The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of selected regions shows the lattice fringes, which could be clearly calculated to be 0.281 nm of the ZnO (1 0 0) plane (e) and 0.205 nm of the Co (1 1 1) plane (e). The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping image implies that elements Zn, Al, and O are evenly distributed on the 3DOM structure, whereas Co distributes randomly in the frame due to the uneven distribution of Co-NC particles in the 3DOM skeleton (f).

elements.content: The collected XRD patterns of Co-NC@AZO, ZIF-8@AZO, AZO, and 3DOM ZnO (ZnO) are presented in a and S5. The three characteristic peaks shown in Figure S5 at 31, 34, and 36° attribute to the (1 0 0), (0 0 2), and (1 0 1) planes of ZnO. Note that the AZO retains the lattice of ZnO with peaks slightly shifting to higher degrees, which can be explained by the slight lattice shrinkage of partly replaced Zn2+ by Al3+ (2 mol %). Moreover, the characteristic peak of ZIF-8 between 5 and 20° can be found in the ZIF-8@AZO and the pure ZIF-8, proving the successful formation of ZIF-8 crystals in the 3DOM framework. The electrical conductivities of these samples were measured by the four-point probe method (b). The conductivity of AZO (7.8 S cm–1) is 4 orders of magnitude higher than that of ZnO (8.6 × 10–4 S cm–1), implying that a proper doping of Al can significantly enhance the electrical conductivity of ZnO. When ZIF-8 forms on AZO, the electrical conductivity slightly decreases to 5.4 S cm–1, which can be improved back to an even higher 9.8 S cm–1 after carbonization. c depicts the density of states (DOS) patterns of ZnO and AZO to further prove the good conductivity of AZO. The DOS pattern of ZnO shows distinct energy gaps with a typical semiconducting character. When Al is introduced into the lattice of ZnO to replace Zn atoms, a new DOS appears around the Fermi energy to narrow the band gap, which significantly improves its electrical conductivity. Moreover, a higher Zn d band center can be observed for AZO (−1.55 eV) compared with that of ZnO (−2.80 eV); see Figure S6. That is, the introduction of Al significantly upshifts the d band center of Zn, thereby enhancing its adsorption ability toward polysulfide.

elements.content: To verify the porosity of the samples, nitrogen adsorption–desorption measurements were performed. As illustrated in d,e, AZO shows very low N2 adsorption capacity. However, both ZIF-8@AZO and Co-NC@AZO exhibit high uptakes in the low P/P 0 range, which corresponds to the micro-/mesoporous structure of MOFs and Co-NC. The BET surface area of Co-NC@AZO is calculated to be 209.80 m2 g–1, and its total pore volume is 0.47 cm3 g–1, which is significantly higher than those of AZO (88.96 m2 g–1, 0.18 cm3 g–1) but lower than those of ZIF-8@AZO (935.01 m2 g–1, 0.65 cm3 g–1). This result suggests that a portion of the ZIF-8 was decomposed during the carbonization process to produce catalytic Co nanoparticles for improved LiPS conversion. The rich micro-/mesopores are expected to benefit for the inhibition of LiPS shuttle effect. The Raman spectra of Co-NC@AZO, ZIF-8@AZO, and AZO are displayed in f. The sharp peak at 1341 cm–1 is ascribed to the D-band of sp3 defects for amorphous carbon, and the distinct peak at 1582 cm–1 can be ascribed to the G-band from the in-plane vibration of graphitic layers. Raman spectra are used to evaluate the microcrystalline graphite domain lengths along the lateral ab direction (L a) of samples according to the following L a ( nm ) = ( 2.4 × 10 − 10 ) λ n m 4 ( I G / I D ) where λ (nm) is the wavelength of the laser (532 nm), I G and I D are the intensity of the G band and D band, respectively. The I D/I G (area) values of Co-NC@AZO, ZIF-8@AZO, and AZO are 2.09, 2.69, and 2.29, respectively, and the corresponding L a values are calculated as 9.19, 7.14, and 8.39 nm, respectively. ZIF-8@AZO exhibits a higher I D/I G (area) value and shorter length of L a than AZO, implying a lower proportion of graphitic layers introduced by ZIF-8, which can be confirmed by the slightly decreased conductivity of ZIF-8@AZO than AZO (b), while Co-NC@AZO displays the lowest I D/I G (area) value and the highest L a value, demonstrating that the carbonization process increases the degree of graphitization, compensating for the loss of electrical conductivity due to the introduction of nongraphite carbon (from 5.4 to 9.8 S cm–1, b). The surface chemistry of the obtained Co-NC@AZO was studied by XPS. The two peaks at 1022.2 and 1045.2 eV in g can be ascribed to Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2, respectively, and the peak at 74.5 eV in h is assigned to Al 2p, demonstrating the existence of Zn and Al. Meanwhile, i shows a sharp peak at 778.6 eV, verifying the existence of the metallic Co state. The emergence of C–N and CN species in fitted C 1s confirms the successful doping of N in the carbon lattice (Figure S7c). Additionally, as shown in Figure S7b, four peaks can be obtained in the N 1s spectrum, which are assigned to pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, graphitic-N, and oxidized-N groups. Note that in N-containing metal/carbon systems, for example, MOF-derived carbonous materials, the formation of N-metal sites is a regular phenomenon under elevated-temperature pyrolysis treatment. Therefore, the appearance of pyrrolic-N and pyridinic-N peaks may likely represent the N–Co bond here. The sulfur contents in Co-NC@AZO, ZIF-8@AZO, and AZO calculated from TGA are 74.5, 65.3, and 58.2 wt %, respectively, which can be found in Figure S8. It is worth noting that ZIF-8@AZO and AZO exhibit lower sulfur loading than Co-NC@AZO. The reason is that the large number of Zn-2-MeIM pieces in ZIF-8@AZO occupy too much space of the AZO macropores, thus hindering the sulfur infusion. Also, AZO causes sulfur loss due to the small BET surface area of 88.96 m2 g–1, which is insufficient to hold much sulfur. While for the Co-NC@AZO, the partial breakdown of ZIF-8 to form Co-NC during the carbonization process exposes a large amount of macro-/mesoporous space, resulting in a relatively proper BET surface area of 209.80 m2 g–1 that can be used to store more sulfur.

elements.content: The electrochemical performance of different samples was explored. The CV curves of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode measured at 0.1 mV s–1 are shown in a. Two reduction peaks at C1 (2.29 V) and C2 (2.04 V) can be observed during the discharging process, corresponding to the sequential transformation of S8 to soluble Li2S x (4 < x < 8) and insoluble Li2S2/Li2S, respectively. In the charging process, the CV curves show a twin oxidation peak at A1 (2.31 V) and A2 (2.38 V), representing the reversible oxidation of Li2S2/Li2S to S8. In addition, the fifth-cycle CV curve overlaps with the first cycle, indicating the excellent durability of the Co-NC@AZO/S electrode. On the other hand, the ZIF-8@AZO/S cathode shows lower reduction peaks and higher polarization voltages compared with the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode (Figure S9), demonstrating its slower electrochemical kinetics originating from poor conductivity of ZIF-8. Moreover, the galvanostatic charge/discharge profiles of different cathodes at 0.2 C are presented in b and S10. Specifically, the potential difference value (η) is defined as the distance between the charging and discharging plateaus at half capacity, representing the degree of polarization. In Figure S10, the gap between the charge and discharge plateaus of the AZO/S cathode is much smaller than the ZnO/S cathode, indicating less polarization and improved conductivity of the AZO/S cathode. Meanwhile, the charge/discharge profile of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode shows the lowest polarization (η = 0.14 V) and the most stable voltage plateau compared to that of the ZIF-8@AZO/S and AZO/S cathodes (b). This indicates that the electrochemical reaction dynamics was enhanced in the conductive Co-NC@AZO. In b,c, the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode presents an initial discharge capacity of 1206.18 mA h g–1 with a decent capacity decay of 12.7% over 100 cycles at 0.2 C. However, the discharge capacities of ZIF-8@AZO/S and AZO/S cathodes drop rapidly to 694.0 and 489.22 mA h g–1 after 100 cycles, with a decay capacity of 27.8 and 54.7%, respectively. Thus, the Co-NC@AZO cathode inherits advantages of both ZIF-8@AZO and AZO, presenting excellent cycle stability and the highest discharge capacity. The Co2+ concentration for Zn2+ substitution and the annealing temperature to obtain Co-NC@AZO were also optimized. In Figure S11, the Co-NC@AZO/S–Co: 0.70 mmol cathode exhibits a higher capacity and cycling stability at 0.2 C than the Co-NC@AZO/S–Co: 1.40 mmol and Co-NC@AZO/S–Co: 0.35 mmol cathodes, implying that appropriate Co content can contribute to improved cell performance. Additionally, the Co-NC@AZO/S-600 °C cathode has the highest capacity when compared to the Co-NC@AZO/S-800 °C and Co-NC@AZO/S-400 °C cathodes in Figure S12. The increase of calcination temperature could enlarge the size of Co nanoparticles but lead to their agglomeration, whereas an inadequate temperature may result in incomplete decomposition of ZIF-8 to produce Co nanoparticles with both of the situations leading to insufficient active sites for LiPS catalytic conversion. Therefore, the Co-NC@AZO with a Co content of 0.70 mmol and calcination temperature of 600 °C was adopted as the optimal cathode.

elements.content: The rate performance of the samples was also studied. The results show that the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode delivers a discharge capacity of 1489.6, 1246.1, 1166.1, 1044.0, 880.9, 743.2, and 635.5 mA h g–1 at C-rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, and 5 C, respectively (d). When the current density was adjusted back to 0.2 C after 70 cycles, the capacity recovers to as high as 97.3% of the initial value under 0.2 C, demonstrating the excellent rate performance of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode. In contrast, the ZIF-8@AZO/S and AZO/S cathodes suffer from poor rate retention at 5 C and inferior capacity recovery. In addition, the galvanostatic charge–discharge profiles of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode show a stable plateau at different current densities with the Coulombic efficiency approaching 100% (e). EIS was tested before and after the cycling process to explore the charge transfer of different cathodes (f and S13). The Nyquist curves consist of two typical parts: one semicircle in the high-frequency region, which can reflect the charge transfer resistance (R ct), and a straight line in the low-frequency region related to ion diffusion resistance, which represents the mass transfer process into the electrode. The EIS curves before discharge in f reveal that the R ct of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode (10.0 Ω) is much lower than that of ZIF-8@AZO/S (33.7 Ω) and AZO/S (59.3 Ω) cathodes, verifying the higher conductivity of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode. After 100 cycles at 0.2 C, the R ct of these electrodes was significantly decreased due to the high concentration of conductive Li2S x formation in the electrolyte (Figure S11). Meanwhile, the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode still presents the lowest R ct compared with ZIF-8@AZO/S and AZO/S cathodes. When tested at 1 C, a high capacity retention of 950.03 mA h g–1 was achieved after 500 cycles for the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode, with a low capacity decay rate of only 0.020% per cycle (g), demonstrating the outstanding polysulfide retention capability.

elements.content: Repeated volume fluctuations of sulfur particles during charging and discharging can damage the cathode structure. Therefore, the SEM images of the Co-NC@AZO cathode before and after 100 cycles at 1 C with sulfur washed off were investigated to reveal the structural stability of Co-NC@AZO. As illustrated in Figure S14c,d, the intact and well-defined 3DOM structure of AZO still remains without structural collapse after cycling. Meanwhile, the Co-NC particles attach well to the AZO framework with almost no Co loss, confirmed by EDS analysis (Figure S14e,f). The good structural stability of Co-NC@AZO is conducive to tolerating the volume expansion of sulfur and thus improving the cycle life of Li–S batteries. Furthermore, the feasibility of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode with higher sulfur loadings of 2.4, 5.2, and 6.8 mg cm–2 was also explored. h and S15 present the cycling performance of Co-NC@AZO/S electrodes at different sulfur loadings and electrolyte-to-sulfur ratios (E/S). Satisfactorily, a decent areal capacity of 5.8 mA h cm–2 after 100 cycles is accessible even at a high sulfur loading of 6.8 mg cm–2. This highlights the advanced electrochemical performance of Co-NC@AZO to achieve high utilization of sulfur. More impressively, the volumetric capacity of Co-NC@AZO/S-based Li–S cells is as high as 1240 mA h cm–3, which is much higher than those of the commercialized lithium-ion batteries (<200 mA h cm–3) and is comparable or even superior to the reported Li–S batteries with efficient composite cathodes (Figure S16 and Table S1). Additionally, the high sulfur loading electrode (6.8 mg cm–2) is controlled at a low E/S ratio of 5.7 μL mg–1, presenting high specific density for practical applications.

Therefore, the SEM images of the Co-NC@AZO cathode before and after 100 cycles at 1 C with sulfur washed off were investigated to reveal the structural stability of Co-NC@AZO. As illustrated in Figure S14c,d, the intact and well-defined 3DOM structure of AZO still remains without structural collapse after cycling. Meanwhile, the Co-NC particles attach well to the AZO framework with almost no Co loss, confirmed by EDS analysis (Figure S14e,f). The good structural stability of Co-NC@AZO is conducive to tolerating the volume expansion of sulfur and thus improving the cycle life of Li-S batteries. Furthermore, the feasibility of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode with higher sulfur loadings of 2.4, 5.2, and 6.8 mg cm-2 was also explored. h and S15 present the cycling performance of Co-NC@AZO/S electrodes at different sulfur loadings and electrolyte-to-sulfur ratios (E/S). Satisfactorily, a decent areal capacity of 5.8 mA h cm-2 after 100 cycles is accessible even at a high sulfur loading of 6.8 mg cm-2. This highlights the advanced electrochemical performance of Co-NC@AZO to achieve high utilization of sulfur. More impressively, the volumetric capacity of Co-NC@AZO/S-based Li-S cells is as high as 1240 mA h cm-3, which is much higher than those of the commercialized lithium-ion batteries (<200 mA h cm-3) and is comparable or even superior to the reported Li-S batteries with efficient composite cathodes (Figure S16 and Table S1). Additionally, the high sulfur loading electrode (6.8 mg cm-2) is controlled at a low E/S ratio of 5.7 μL mg-1, presenting high specific density for practical applications.

elements.content: The CV measurements of Co-NC@AZO/S, ZIF-8@AZO/S, and AZO/S cathodes were performed to investigate Li+ diffusion kinetics, which has a significant impact on LiPS conversion during the charge/discharge process. As shown in a–c, the variation of peaks can be observed with the scan rate in the triple electrode system. Insofar as for the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode, the C1 and C2 peaks negatively migrate by 0.028 and 0.084 V, whereas the A2 peak positively migrates by 0.071 V when the scan rate rises from 0.1 to 0.5 mV s–1. Similar phenomena of peak migrations were observed from ZIF-8@AZO/S and AZO/S cathodes but with larger interval extents: the values for C1, C2, and A2 peak migration are 0.031, 0.107 and 0.075 V, respectively, for ZIF-8@AZO/S and 0.034, 0.087, and 0.077 V, respectively, for AZO/S (b,c). This implies that Co-NC@AZO exhibits the lowest polarization activation among the three cathodes, demonstrating the most efficient conversion kinetics of Li2S x . Note that a weak anodic peak at around 2.6 V can be found for the Co-NC@AZO/S and ZIF-8@AZO/S cathodes, which gradually disappears as the scan speed increases during the test. This may be caused by an unknown reaction, which will be studied in detail in our future work. Moreover, the Li-ion diffusion coefficient (D Li) of different cathodes could be estimated according to the Randles–Sevcik I p = ( 2.69 × 10 5 ) n 1.5 D L i 0.5 C Li v 0.5

elements.content: Accordingly, the value of I p/v 0.5 (slope of peak current vs the square root of the scanning rate) can signify D Li (Li-ion diffusion coefficient) as A (electrode surface area), n (the number of charge transfer), and C Li (Li-ion concentration) are constant. As shown in d–f, the slopes for the two reduction peaks and the oxidation peak of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode are larger than those of ZIF-8@AZO/S and AZO/S cathodes. The D Li calculated according to is shown in Figure S17. The Co-NC@AZO/S cathode demonstrates superior D Li of 2.134 × 10–7, 3.742 × 10–8, and 8.141 × 10–8 cm2 s–1 for peaks A2, C1, and C2, respectively, which are higher than those of ZIF-8@AZO and AZO. Note that the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode presents stronger Li+ diffusion ability than the AZO/S cathode, which may be attributed to the following three points: (i) the Co-NC nanocages promote the formation of multistage porous architecture, which can provide more Li+ transfer pathways; (ii) the robust LiPS adsorption capacity of the Co-NC nanocages reduces the concentration of LiPS dissolved in the electrolyte, resulting in a relatively low-viscosity electrolyte to allow easier Li+ movement; (iii) Li+ transfer more easily on the surface of Co-NC with a low energy barrier.

elements.content: The adsorption of LiPS by different samples was studied to validate the LiPS immobilization capacity of the designed materials. First, a visualized adsorption experiment was carried out using Li2S6 solution with the assistance of UV–vis absorption spectroscopy. As shown in g, equal amounts of Co-NC@AZO, ZIF-8@AZO, and AZO powders were added separately into 10 mM Li2S6 solution. One can see that the Li2S6 solution containing Co-NC@AZO becomes colorless after standing for 24 h, along with the lowest absorption peak in UV–vis absorption spectroscopy, representing a strong interaction between LiPS and Co-NC@AZO. On the other hand, the Li2S6 solution with ZIF-8@AZO remains faint yellow, implying the insufficient chemical adsorption of ZIF-8@AZO despite its high specific surface area. The solution with AZO presents the weakest Li2S6 adsorption effect due to the lack of both meso-/micropores and sufficient chemical interaction. Besides, the strong interaction between LiPS and Co-NC@AZO was further demonstrated by XPS analysis. In h, the S 2p spectrum of pure Li2S6 displays two pairs of peaks at 161.8 and 163.5 eV associated with the terminal (ST –1) and bridging sulfur (SB 0), respectively. Upon interaction with Co-NC@AZO (Li2S6@Co-NC@AZO), respective shifts of identical peaks to higher binding energies occur, indicating the strong affinity of Co-NC@AZO to LiPS by the freshly formed metal-S (e.g., Zn–S and Al–S) bond. Apart from that, the Li2S6@Co-NC@AZO sample shows a new distinctive S 2p peak at 168.7 eV, suggesting the formation of thiosulfate, which results from the oxidation of sulfur species on the surface of Co-NC@AZO. Analogously, Figure S18 shows that the Li 1s spectrum of Li2S6@Co-NC@AZO exhibits an extra peak at 56.4 eV, which can be ascribed to the Li–N/O bond, marking the potential increase of LiPS adsorption. To understand the adsorption mechanism of the Co-NC@AZO at the atomic level, DFT calculations were implemented on AZO(1 0 0) and Co(1 1 1) surfaces (i and S20). It can be seen that the Li atom in Li2S2 and Li2S6 prefers to bond with the O atom of the AZO, whereas the S atom in LiPS prefers to bond with the Zn and Al atoms. The binding energies (E ab) of Li2S2 and Li2S6 on the AZO(1 0 0) surface are calculated to be as high as −4.01 and −4.23 eV, respectively. In comparison, Li2S6 on the ZnO(1 0 0) shows a relatively weak adsorption of −2.62 eV (Figure S19). Additionally, the E ab of Li2S on Co(1 1 1) is calculated to be −4.04 eV (Figure S20), proving enhanced chemical adsorption compared with ZIF-8@AZO and AZO where Co nanoparticles are absent (g). According to the above analysis, the strong adhesion of LiPS species on the surface of Co-NC@AZO can effectively prevent the loss of the active material.

elements.content: As shown in a, symmetric cells of different cathodes with Li2S6 were measured at 5 mV s–1. Compared with ZIF-8@AZO and AZO, the CV curve of Co-NC@AZO exhibits higher response current, indicating its adequate sulfur utilization and prominent conversion kinetics for the redox of LiPS. Furthermore, the Co-NC@AZO cell has two different pairs of redox peaks, which are located at −0.24/0.24 and −0.43/0.43 V. On the other hand, the ZIF-8@AZO cell exhibits a larger polarization voltage with only one pair of broader redox peaks at −0.51/0.51 V. This distinct difference of the two composite verifies the minimal polarization voltage and rapid conversion kinetics of LiPS on Co-NC@AZO. In addition, Co-NC@AZO also shows high reversibility with no distinctive potential shift in the first three cycles, illustrating that the Co-NC@AZO owns a superior ability for polysulfide trapping and cycle stability (Figure S21). Besides, the EIS spectra show that a symmetrical cell with Co-NC@AZO has the lowest R ct among the three electrodes (Figure S22), demonstrating its fast charge transfer during the LiPS conversion process. To gain in-depth insights into the origin of the superior LiPS conversion kinetics on Co-NC@AZO, the electrocatalytic properties of different cathode materials were investigated. As presented in b, the electrocatalytic activity of Co-NC@AZO toward Li2S oxidation is assessed in comparison with those of ZIF-8@AZO, AZO, and glassy carbon through LSV measurements. The results show that Co-NC@AZO provides the highest current response of 0.94 mA and the lowest onset potential of −0.6 V compared with ZIF-8@AZO (0.64 mA, −0.53 V) and AZO (0.34 mA, −0.48 V) at 5 mV s–1, demonstrating the superior catalytic activity of Co-NC@AZO. This can be further verified by the Tafel plots shown in the inset of b, in which Co-NC@AZO has a lower slope of 20 mV dec–1 compared with those for ZIF-8@AZO (27 mV dec–1) and AZO (39 mV dec–1), indicating the fast oxidization reactions of Li2S on the Co-NC@AZO surface. To further reveal the catalytic activity of Co-NC@AZO toward LiPS conversion from the theoretical perspective, DFT calculations were conducted by considering the decomposition ability of Li2S on catalytically active surfaces. c and S23 show the Li2S decomposition pathways on the Co (1 1 1) and Co–4N–C surface models. The results show that the decomposition energy barrier of Li2S on Co (1 1 1) is as small as 0.17 eV, which ensures the effective catalytic decomposition of Li2S. Besides, a rapid reduction reaction from LiPS to Li2S is also critical for an efficient LiPS conversion process. Therefore, the liquid–solid conversion process of LiPS was tested by nucleation and growth experiments of Li2S to inspect the reduction kinetics of different electrodes. As given in d–f, Co-NC@AZO exhibits the highest capacity and earliest responsivity (345.66 mA h g–1, 1170 s) of Li2S nucleation compared with ZIF-8@AZO (245.25 mA h g–1, 1222 s) and AZO (171.33 mA h g–1, 1369 s), confirming the high capability and rapid nucleation kinetics of Li2S, which contributes to the fast and efficient electrochemistry of the Co-NC@AZO sulfur host.

elements.content: Flexible and foldable pouch cells with the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode were further explored. Based on the schematic illustration (a), a large-area (3 × 4 cm2) pouch cell with high S loading (4 mg cm–2) was fabricated, and the corresponding E/S ratio was 5.2 μL mg–1. Experimentally, an open-circuit voltage (OCV) of 2.66 V was achieved by the Li–S pouch cell. It can successfully power a red light-emitting diode (LED) as shown in b. Moreover, the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode has the ability to illuminate LED badges under various bending conditions (c). No apparent change in the LED brightness can be observed during the bending and folding process. Also, even when flattening and folding again, the series resistance remains unchanged and the R ct is only slightly increased, convincingly verifying the high flexibility and robustness of the Co-NC@AZO-based pouch cell. In addition, outstanding performance in cycling stability is also observed in the Co-NC@AZO/S-based pouch cell, which liberates a satisfactory specific capacity of 897.5 mA h g–1 under 0.1 C after 100 cycles. The superior stability of the pouch cell is mainly due to the excellent trapping capacity of sulfur species by the designed Co-NC@AZO cathode: the macro-/microporous multistage architecture provides a mass of adsorption sites for LiPS; the strong polar adsorption for LiPS by AZO and Co-NC suppresses the shuttle effect; the catalytic effect of Co-NC significantly enhances the electrochemical redox kinetics of LiPS (d). The reduced polysulfide dissolution limits the decreased ionic conductivity, rapid lithium metal anode corrosion, premature precipitation of LiPS in the electrolyte, and the accompanying sulfur loss, which are considered as the main reasons for pouch cell failure. As a result, the design of multifunctional Co-NC@AZO electrodes is of significant potential for practical electronics and portable storage applications. In the future work, the production of Li–S pouch cells with high specific energy and long cycle life is a subject for new ideas related to materials, electrode structures, and electrolytes.

elements.content: In summary, a hierarchical structure consisting of AZO as the conductive ordered macroporous framework and embedded Co-NC as the microporous catalytic nanoparticles is rationally designed and successfully prepared as an advanced sulfur immobilizer and catalytical promoter. The AZO material possesses both excellent polysulfide adsorption and good electronic conductivity, whereas the macroporous framework accelerates the mass transportation and electrolyte infiltration, simultaneously providing plentiful and accessible sites for strong LiPS adsorption. Meanwhile, micro-/mesoporous Co-NC is embedded in the macropores to further strengthen the LiPS adsorption as well as catalytically accelerate LiPS conversion kinetics at the same time. Attributed to the material and structural superiorities, the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode delivers a low capacity decay of 0.020% per cycle for 500 cycles at 1 C, exhibiting a notable rate capability of 635.5 mA h g–1 up to 5 C. Especially, at a S loading of 6.8 mg cm–2, a high areal capacity of 5.8 mA h cm–2 is achieved under lean electrolyte conditions (E/S = 5.7). With these benefits, the pouch cell based on the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode also provides excellent long-term stability of 897.5 mA h g–1 within 100 cycles at 0.1 C under 4 mg cm–2 sulfur loading. This work offers a strategy for a superior sulfur host with hierarchical architecture and multifunction to achieve effective anchoring and conversion of LiPS, holding great promises in practical application in Li–S batteries.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a hierarchical structure consisting of AZO as the conductive ordered macroporous framework and embedded Co-NC as the microporous catalytic nanoparticles is rationally designed and successfully prepared as an advanced sulfur immobilizer and catalytical promoter. The AZO material possesses both excellent polysulfide adsorption and good electronic conductivity, whereas the macroporous framework accelerates the mass transportation and electrolyte infiltration, simultaneously providing plentiful and accessible sites for strong LiPS adsorption. Meanwhile, micro-/mesoporous Co-NC is embedded in the macropores to further strengthen the LiPS adsorption as well as catalytically accelerate LiPS conversion kinetics at the same time. Attributed to the material and structural superiorities, the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode delivers a low capacity decay of 0.020% per cycle for 500 cycles at 1 C, exhibiting a notable rate capability of 635.5 mA h g-1 up to 5 C. Especially, at a S loading of 6.8 mg cm-2, a high areal capacity of 5.8 mA h cm-2 is achieved under lean electrolyte conditions (E/S = 5.7). With these benefits, the pouch cell based on the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode also provides excellent long-term stability of 897.5 mA h g-1 within 100 cycles at 0.1 C under 4 mg cm-2 sulfur loading. This work offers a strategy for a superior sulfur host with hierarchical architecture and multifunction to achieve effective anchoring and conversion of LiPS, holding great promises in practical application in Li-S batteries.

cln_elements.content:
First, polystyrene (PS) spheres 290 nm in diameter were prepared as a macroporous template according to the literature. For generating ZnO, Zn­(NO3)3·6H2O (2.2 g) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL) with continuous stirring. After that, citric acid (0.6 g) was added as a chelating agent to the above solution and uninterruptedly stirred for 30 min. Then, PS spheres (2.0 g) were dipped in the above metal precursor solution and allowed to stand for 4 h. Subsequently, the suspension was filtered by vacuum filtration to remove the excess solution. Following vacuum drying at 60 °C, the dried sample was thermally treated in a tube furnace at 300 °C in Ar for 60 min following ramping at a rate of 1 °C min–1. Then, the temperature was raised again to 500 °C and maintained for 2 h under Ar at a ramping rate of 1 °C min–1. Finally, the ZnO powder was cooled to room temperature and collected. The AZO powder was synthesized by the same method with the addition of a certain amount of Al­(NO3)3·9H2O.

Li<sub>2</sub>S Nucleation Characterizations

The Li2S8 solution was synthesized via mixing Li2S and S at a molar ratio of 1:7 in a solution of tetraglyme and LiTFSI (1 M) and then was stirred continuously at 60 °C for 24 h. The cell was discharged to 2.06 V under a continuous current of 0.112 mA and then kept at a constant voltage of 2.05 V until the current dropped below 0.1 mA.

cln_elements.content:
Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries possess many practical challenges including the lithium polysulfide (LiPS) “shuttle effect” and their sluggish conversion kinetics. To address these issues, a unique hierarchical porous architecture, combining highly conductive ordered macroporous skeleton and embedded microporous particles is rationally designed as a dual-effective polysulfide immobilizer and conversion promoter. In this nanoporous architecture, Al-doped ZnO (AZO) acts as a conductive macroporous framework, profiting chemical anchoring of LiPS as well as facilitating electrolyte infiltration and ion diffusion; Co nanoparticle-anchored N-doped carbon (Co-NC) derived from CoZn-metal–organic framework is embedded in the macropores to further strengthen the LiPS adsorption, catalytically accelerating conversion kinetics of LiPS simultaneously. Consequently, the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode delivers a notable rate capability of 635.5 mA h g–1 at 5 C. A high area capacity of about 5.8 mA h cm–2 with a mass loading of 6.8 mg cm–2 is also achieved under a lean electrolyte (E/S = 5.7). Additionally, the Li–S pouch cells equipped with Co-NC@AZO can be extended to sulfur loading as high as 4.0 mg cm–2, delivering a superb capability of 897.5 mA h g–1 after 100 cycles. This work puts forward a design for stably cycled and practically viable Li–S batteries.

Herein, a highly conductive and polar three-dimensional ordered macroporous (3DOM) framework was developed by Al-doped ZnO (AZO), a commonly used conductive oxide in photovoltaics. The inherent polarity of 3DOM AZO can provide strengthened LiPS adsorption. In addition, the high conductivity and ordered macropores can efficiently accelerate charge transportation and transfer, electrolyte infiltration, and ion diffusion. To further boost the surface area and corresponding reaction sites, microporous Co-decorated N-doped carbon (Co-NC), derived from the carbonization of the CoZn-MOF, was introduced within the macropores of 3DOM AZO, forming a novel hierarchical porous structure. The microporous Co-NC provides plentiful and accessible active sites of Co nanoparticles as well as N-doped carbon for strong LiPS adsorption and its effective catalytic conversion during charge/discharge cycling, ensuring a high utilization rate of sulfur in lean electrolyte conditions. Combined with these merits, the CoZn-NC@AZO/S cathode exhibits superb cycling stability over 500 cycles at 1 C with a low capacity fading rate of 0.020% per cycle and a high capacity of 635.5 mA h g–1 at 5 C. Furthermore, a high area capacity of 5.8 mA h cm–2 with a sulfur loading of 6.8 mg cm–2 is also achieved at a low electrolyte-to-sulfur ratio (E/S = 5.7). More importantly, the multifunctional CoZn-NC@AZO cathode also shows excellent electrochemical performance in a pouch cell. A high capacity of 897.5 mA h g–1 can be obtained even after 100 cycles at 0.1 C under a sulfur loading of 4.0 mg cm–2 and E/S ratio of 5.2 μL mg–1. Also, the excellent flexibility of the pouch cell is displayed under flat and bending states. This study proposes a novel design strategy for advanced and practicable Li–S batteries.

The collected XRD patterns of Co-NC@AZO, ZIF-8@AZO, AZO, and 3DOM ZnO (ZnO) are presented in a and S5. The three characteristic peaks shown in Figure S5 at 31, 34, and 36° attribute to the (1 0 0), (0 0 2), and (1 0 1) planes of ZnO. Note that the AZO retains the lattice of ZnO with peaks slightly shifting to higher degrees, which can be explained by the slight lattice shrinkage of partly replaced Zn2+ by Al3+ (2 mol %). Moreover, the characteristic peak of ZIF-8 between 5 and 20° can be found in the ZIF-8@AZO and the pure ZIF-8, proving the successful formation of ZIF-8 crystals in the 3DOM framework. The electrical conductivities of these samples were measured by the four-point probe method (b). The conductivity of AZO (7.8 S cm–1) is 4 orders of magnitude higher than that of ZnO (8.6 × 10–4 S cm–1), implying that a proper doping of Al can significantly enhance the electrical conductivity of ZnO. When ZIF-8 forms on AZO, the electrical conductivity slightly decreases to 5.4 S cm–1, which can be improved back to an even higher 9.8 S cm–1 after carbonization. c depicts the density of states (DOS) patterns of ZnO and AZO to further prove the good conductivity of AZO. The DOS pattern of ZnO shows distinct energy gaps with a typical semiconducting character. When Al is introduced into the lattice of ZnO to replace Zn atoms, a new DOS appears around the Fermi energy to narrow the band gap, which significantly improves its electrical conductivity. Moreover, a higher Zn d band center can be observed for AZO (−1.55 eV) compared with that of ZnO (−2.80 eV); see Figure S6. That is, the introduction of Al significantly upshifts the d band center of Zn, thereby enhancing its adsorption ability toward polysulfide.

To verify the porosity of the samples, nitrogen adsorption–desorption measurements were performed. As illustrated in d,e, AZO shows very low N2 adsorption capacity. However, both ZIF-8@AZO and Co-NC@AZO exhibit high uptakes in the low P/P 0 range, which corresponds to the micro-/mesoporous structure of MOFs and Co-NC. The BET surface area of Co-NC@AZO is calculated to be 209.80 m2 g–1, and its total pore volume is 0.47 cm3 g–1, which is significantly higher than those of AZO (88.96 m2 g–1, 0.18 cm3 g–1) but lower than those of ZIF-8@AZO (935.01 m2 g–1, 0.65 cm3 g–1). This result suggests that a portion of the ZIF-8 was decomposed during the carbonization process to produce catalytic Co nanoparticles for improved LiPS conversion. The rich micro-/mesopores are expected to benefit for the inhibition of LiPS shuttle effect. The Raman spectra of Co-NC@AZO, ZIF-8@AZO, and AZO are displayed in f. The sharp peak at 1341 cm–1 is ascribed to the D-band of sp3 defects for amorphous carbon, and the distinct peak at 1582 cm–1 can be ascribed to the G-band from the in-plane vibration of graphitic layers. Raman spectra are used to evaluate the microcrystalline graphite domain lengths along the lateral ab direction (L a) of samples according to the following L a ( nm ) = ( 2.4 × 10 − 10 ) λ n m 4 ( I G / I D ) where λ (nm) is the wavelength of the laser (532 nm), I G and I D are the intensity of the G band and D band, respectively. The I D/I G (area) values of Co-NC@AZO, ZIF-8@AZO, and AZO are 2.09, 2.69, and 2.29, respectively, and the corresponding L a values are calculated as 9.19, 7.14, and 8.39 nm, respectively. ZIF-8@AZO exhibits a higher I D/I G (area) value and shorter length of L a than AZO, implying a lower proportion of graphitic layers introduced by ZIF-8, which can be confirmed by the slightly decreased conductivity of ZIF-8@AZO than AZO (b), while Co-NC@AZO displays the lowest I D/I G (area) value and the highest L a value, demonstrating that the carbonization process increases the degree of graphitization, compensating for the loss of electrical conductivity due to the introduction of nongraphite carbon (from 5.4 to 9.8 S cm–1, b). The surface chemistry of the obtained Co-NC@AZO was studied by XPS. The two peaks at 1022.2 and 1045.2 eV in g can be ascribed to Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2, respectively, and the peak at 74.5 eV in h is assigned to Al 2p, demonstrating the existence of Zn and Al. Meanwhile, i shows a sharp peak at 778.6 eV, verifying the existence of the metallic Co state. The emergence of C–N and CN species in fitted C 1s confirms the successful doping of N in the carbon lattice (Figure S7c). Additionally, as shown in Figure S7b, four peaks can be obtained in the N 1s spectrum, which are assigned to pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, graphitic-N, and oxidized-N groups. Note that in N-containing metal/carbon systems, for example, MOF-derived carbonous materials, the formation of N-metal sites is a regular phenomenon under elevated-temperature pyrolysis treatment. Therefore, the appearance of pyrrolic-N and pyridinic-N peaks may likely represent the N–Co bond here. The sulfur contents in Co-NC@AZO, ZIF-8@AZO, and AZO calculated from TGA are 74.5, 65.3, and 58.2 wt %, respectively, which can be found in Figure S8. It is worth noting that ZIF-8@AZO and AZO exhibit lower sulfur loading than Co-NC@AZO. The reason is that the large number of Zn-2-MeIM pieces in ZIF-8@AZO occupy too much space of the AZO macropores, thus hindering the sulfur infusion. Also, AZO causes sulfur loss due to the small BET surface area of 88.96 m2 g–1, which is insufficient to hold much sulfur. While for the Co-NC@AZO, the partial breakdown of ZIF-8 to form Co-NC during the carbonization process exposes a large amount of macro-/mesoporous space, resulting in a relatively proper BET surface area of 209.80 m2 g–1 that can be used to store more sulfur.

cln_elements.content:
The electrochemical performance of different samples was explored. The CV curves of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode measured at 0.1 mV s–1 are shown in a. Two reduction peaks at C1 (2.29 V) and C2 (2.04 V) can be observed during the discharging process, corresponding to the sequential transformation of S8 to soluble Li2S x (4 < x < 8) and insoluble Li2S2/Li2S, respectively. In the charging process, the CV curves show a twin oxidation peak at A1 (2.31 V) and A2 (2.38 V), representing the reversible oxidation of Li2S2/Li2S to S8. In addition, the fifth-cycle CV curve overlaps with the first cycle, indicating the excellent durability of the Co-NC@AZO/S electrode. On the other hand, the ZIF-8@AZO/S cathode shows lower reduction peaks and higher polarization voltages compared with the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode (Figure S9), demonstrating its slower electrochemical kinetics originating from poor conductivity of ZIF-8. Moreover, the galvanostatic charge/discharge profiles of different cathodes at 0.2 C are presented in b and S10. Specifically, the potential difference value (η) is defined as the distance between the charging and discharging plateaus at half capacity, representing the degree of polarization. In Figure S10, the gap between the charge and discharge plateaus of the AZO/S cathode is much smaller than the ZnO/S cathode, indicating less polarization and improved conductivity of the AZO/S cathode. Meanwhile, the charge/discharge profile of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode shows the lowest polarization (η = 0.14 V) and the most stable voltage plateau compared to that of the ZIF-8@AZO/S and AZO/S cathodes (b). This indicates that the electrochemical reaction dynamics was enhanced in the conductive Co-NC@AZO. In b,c, the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode presents an initial discharge capacity of 1206.18 mA h g–1 with a decent capacity decay of 12.7% over 100 cycles at 0.2 C. However, the discharge capacities of ZIF-8@AZO/S and AZO/S cathodes drop rapidly to 694.0 and 489.22 mA h g–1 after 100 cycles, with a decay capacity of 27.8 and 54.7%, respectively. Thus, the Co-NC@AZO cathode inherits advantages of both ZIF-8@AZO and AZO, presenting excellent cycle stability and the highest discharge capacity. The Co2+ concentration for Zn2+ substitution and the annealing temperature to obtain Co-NC@AZO were also optimized. In Figure S11, the Co-NC@AZO/S–Co: 0.70 mmol cathode exhibits a higher capacity and cycling stability at 0.2 C than the Co-NC@AZO/S–Co: 1.40 mmol and Co-NC@AZO/S–Co: 0.35 mmol cathodes, implying that appropriate Co content can contribute to improved cell performance. Additionally, the Co-NC@AZO/S-600 °C cathode has the highest capacity when compared to the Co-NC@AZO/S-800 °C and Co-NC@AZO/S-400 °C cathodes in Figure S12. The increase of calcination temperature could enlarge the size of Co nanoparticles but lead to their agglomeration, whereas an inadequate temperature may result in incomplete decomposition of ZIF-8 to produce Co nanoparticles with both of the situations leading to insufficient active sites for LiPS catalytic conversion. Therefore, the Co-NC@AZO with a Co content of 0.70 mmol and calcination temperature of 600 °C was adopted as the optimal cathode.

The rate performance of the samples was also studied. The results show that the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode delivers a discharge capacity of 1489.6, 1246.1, 1166.1, 1044.0, 880.9, 743.2, and 635.5 mA h g–1 at C-rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, and 5 C, respectively (d). When the current density was adjusted back to 0.2 C after 70 cycles, the capacity recovers to as high as 97.3% of the initial value under 0.2 C, demonstrating the excellent rate performance of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode. In contrast, the ZIF-8@AZO/S and AZO/S cathodes suffer from poor rate retention at 5 C and inferior capacity recovery. In addition, the galvanostatic charge–discharge profiles of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode show a stable plateau at different current densities with the Coulombic efficiency approaching 100% (e). EIS was tested before and after the cycling process to explore the charge transfer of different cathodes (f and S13). The Nyquist curves consist of two typical parts: one semicircle in the high-frequency region, which can reflect the charge transfer resistance (R ct), and a straight line in the low-frequency region related to ion diffusion resistance, which represents the mass transfer process into the electrode. The EIS curves before discharge in f reveal that the R ct of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode (10.0 Ω) is much lower than that of ZIF-8@AZO/S (33.7 Ω) and AZO/S (59.3 Ω) cathodes, verifying the higher conductivity of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode. After 100 cycles at 0.2 C, the R ct of these electrodes was significantly decreased due to the high concentration of conductive Li2S x formation in the electrolyte (Figure S11). Meanwhile, the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode still presents the lowest R ct compared with ZIF-8@AZO/S and AZO/S cathodes. When tested at 1 C, a high capacity retention of 950.03 mA h g–1 was achieved after 500 cycles for the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode, with a low capacity decay rate of only 0.020% per cycle (g), demonstrating the outstanding polysulfide retention capability.

Repeated volume fluctuations of sulfur particles during charging and discharging can damage the cathode structure. Therefore, the SEM images of the Co-NC@AZO cathode before and after 100 cycles at 1 C with sulfur washed off were investigated to reveal the structural stability of Co-NC@AZO. As illustrated in Figure S14c,d, the intact and well-defined 3DOM structure of AZO still remains without structural collapse after cycling. Meanwhile, the Co-NC particles attach well to the AZO framework with almost no Co loss, confirmed by EDS analysis (Figure S14e,f). The good structural stability of Co-NC@AZO is conducive to tolerating the volume expansion of sulfur and thus improving the cycle life of Li–S batteries. Furthermore, the feasibility of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode with higher sulfur loadings of 2.4, 5.2, and 6.8 mg cm–2 was also explored. h and S15 present the cycling performance of Co-NC@AZO/S electrodes at different sulfur loadings and electrolyte-to-sulfur ratios (E/S). Satisfactorily, a decent areal capacity of 5.8 mA h cm–2 after 100 cycles is accessible even at a high sulfur loading of 6.8 mg cm–2. This highlights the advanced electrochemical performance of Co-NC@AZO to achieve high utilization of sulfur. More impressively, the volumetric capacity of Co-NC@AZO/S-based Li–S cells is as high as 1240 mA h cm–3, which is much higher than those of the commercialized lithium-ion batteries (<200 mA h cm–3) and is comparable or even superior to the reported Li–S batteries with efficient composite cathodes (Figure S16 and Table S1). Additionally, the high sulfur loading electrode (6.8 mg cm–2) is controlled at a low E/S ratio of 5.7 μL mg–1, presenting high specific density for practical applications.

The increase of calcination temperature could enlarge the size of Co nanoparticles but lead to their agglomeration, whereas an inadequate temperature may result in incomplete decomposition of ZIF-8 to produce Co nanoparticles with both of the situations leading to insufficient active sites for LiPS catalytic conversion. Therefore, the Co-NC@AZO with a Co content of 0.70 mmol and calcination temperature of 600 °C was adopted as the optimal cathode.

The rate performance of the samples was also studied. The results show that the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode delivers a discharge capacity of 1489.6, 1246.1, 1166.1, 1044.0, 880.9, 743.2, and 635.5 mA h g-1 at C-rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, and 5 C, respectively (d). When the current density was adjusted back to 0.2 C after 70 cycles, the capacity recovers to as high as 97.3% of the initial value under 0.2 C, demonstrating the excellent rate performance of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode. In contrast, the ZIF-8@AZO/S and AZO/S cathodes suffer from poor rate retention at 5 C and inferior capacity recovery. In addition, the galvanostatic charge-discharge profiles of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode show a stable plateau at different current densities with the Coulombic efficiency approaching 100% (e). EIS was tested before and after the cycling process to explore the charge transfer of different cathodes (f and S13). The Nyquist curves consist of two typical parts: one semicircle in the high-frequency region, which can reflect the charge transfer resistance (R ct), and a straight line in the low-frequency region related to ion diffusion resistance, which represents the mass transfer process into the electrode. The EIS curves before discharge in f reveal that the R ct of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode (10.0 Ω) is much lower than that of ZIF-8@AZO/S (33.7 Ω) and AZO/S (59.3 Ω) cathodes, verifying the higher conductivity of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode. After 100 cycles at 0.2 C, the R ct of these electrodes was significantly decreased due to the high concentration of conductive Li2S x  formation in the electrolyte (Figure S11). Meanwhile, the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode still presents the lowest R ct compared with ZIF-8@AZO/S and AZO/S cathodes. When tested at 1 C, a high capacity retention of 950.03 mA h g-1 was achieved after 500 cycles for the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode, with a low capacity decay rate of only 0.020% per cycle (g), demonstrating the outstanding polysulfide retention capability.

Repeated volume fluctuations of sulfur particles during charging and discharging can damage the cathode structure. Therefore, the SEM images of the Co-NC@AZO cathode before and after 100 cycles at 1 C with sulfur washed off were investigated to reveal the structural stability of Co-NC@AZO. As illustrated in Figure S14c,d, the intact and well-defined 3DOM structure of AZO still remains without structural collapse after cycling. Meanwhile, the Co-NC particles attach well to the AZO framework with almost no Co loss, confirmed by EDS analysis (Figure S14e,f). The good structural stability of Co-NC@AZO is conducive to tolerating the volume expansion of sulfur and thus improving the cycle life of Li-S batteries. Furthermore, the feasibility of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode with higher sulfur loadings of 2.4, 5.2, and 6.8 mg cm-2 was also explored. h and S15 present the cycling performance of Co-NC@AZO/S electrodes at different sulfur loadings and electrolyte-to-sulfur ratios (E/S). Satisfactorily, a decent areal capacity of 5.8 mA h cm-2 after 100 cycles is accessible even at a high sulfur loading of 6.8 mg cm-2. This highlights the advanced electrochemical performance of Co-NC@AZO to achieve high utilization of sulfur. More impressively, the volumetric capacity of Co-NC@AZO/S-based Li-S cells is as high as 1240 mA h cm-3, which is much higher than those of the commercialized lithium-ion batteries (<200 mA h cm-3) and is comparable or even superior to the reported Li-S batteries with efficient composite cathodes (Figure S16 and Table S1). Additionally, the high sulfur loading electrode (6.8 mg cm-2) is controlled at a low E/S ratio of 5.7 μL mg-1, presenting high specific density for practical applications.
