cln_elements.content:
The CV measurements of Co-NC@AZO/S, ZIF-8@AZO/S, and AZO/S cathodes were performed to investigate Li+ diffusion kinetics, which has a significant impact on LiPS conversion during the charge/discharge process. As shown in a–c, the variation of peaks can be observed with the scan rate in the triple electrode system. Insofar as for the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode, the C1 and C2 peaks negatively migrate by 0.028 and 0.084 V, whereas the A2 peak positively migrates by 0.071 V when the scan rate rises from 0.1 to 0.5 mV s–1. Similar phenomena of peak migrations were observed from ZIF-8@AZO/S and AZO/S cathodes but with larger interval extents: the values for C1, C2, and A2 peak migration are 0.031, 0.107 and 0.075 V, respectively, for ZIF-8@AZO/S and 0.034, 0.087, and 0.077 V, respectively, for AZO/S (b,c). This implies that Co-NC@AZO exhibits the lowest polarization activation among the three cathodes, demonstrating the most efficient conversion kinetics of Li2S x . Note that a weak anodic peak at around 2.6 V can be found for the Co-NC@AZO/S and ZIF-8@AZO/S cathodes, which gradually disappears as the scan speed increases during the test. This may be caused by an unknown reaction, which will be studied in detail in our future work. Moreover, the Li-ion diffusion coefficient (D Li) of different cathodes could be estimated according to the Randles–Sevcik I p = ( 2.69 × 10 5 ) n 1.5 D L i 0.5 C Li v 0.5

Accordingly, the value of I p/v 0.5 (slope of peak current vs the square root of the scanning rate) can signify D Li (Li-ion diffusion coefficient) as A (electrode surface area), n (the number of charge transfer), and C Li (Li-ion concentration) are constant. As shown in d–f, the slopes for the two reduction peaks and the oxidation peak of the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode are larger than those of ZIF-8@AZO/S and AZO/S cathodes. The D Li calculated according to is shown in Figure S17. The Co-NC@AZO/S cathode demonstrates superior D Li of 2.134 × 10–7, 3.742 × 10–8, and 8.141 × 10–8 cm2 s–1 for peaks A2, C1, and C2, respectively, which are higher than those of ZIF-8@AZO and AZO. Note that the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode presents stronger Li+ diffusion ability than the AZO/S cathode, which may be attributed to the following three points: (i) the Co-NC nanocages promote the formation of multistage porous architecture, which can provide more Li+ transfer pathways; (ii) the robust LiPS adsorption capacity of the Co-NC nanocages reduces the concentration of LiPS dissolved in the electrolyte, resulting in a relatively low-viscosity electrolyte to allow easier Li+ movement; (iii) Li+ transfer more easily on the surface of Co-NC with a low energy barrier.

As shown in a, symmetric cells of different cathodes with Li2S6 were measured at 5 mV s–1. Compared with ZIF-8@AZO and AZO, the CV curve of Co-NC@AZO exhibits higher response current, indicating its adequate sulfur utilization and prominent conversion kinetics for the redox of LiPS. Furthermore, the Co-NC@AZO cell has two different pairs of redox peaks, which are located at −0.24/0.24 and −0.43/0.43 V. On the other hand, the ZIF-8@AZO cell exhibits a larger polarization voltage with only one pair of broader redox peaks at −0.51/0.51 V. This distinct difference of the two composite verifies the minimal polarization voltage and rapid conversion kinetics of LiPS on Co-NC@AZO. In addition, Co-NC@AZO also shows high reversibility with no distinctive potential shift in the first three cycles, illustrating that the Co-NC@AZO owns a superior ability for polysulfide trapping and cycle stability (Figure S21). Besides, the EIS spectra show that a symmetrical cell with Co-NC@AZO has the lowest R ct among the three electrodes (Figure S22), demonstrating its fast charge transfer during the LiPS conversion process. To gain in-depth insights into the origin of the superior LiPS conversion kinetics on Co-NC@AZO, the electrocatalytic properties of different cathode materials were investigated. As presented in b, the electrocatalytic activity of Co-NC@AZO toward Li2S oxidation is assessed in comparison with those of ZIF-8@AZO, AZO, and glassy carbon through LSV measurements. The results show that Co-NC@AZO provides the highest current response of 0.94 mA and the lowest onset potential of −0.6 V compared with ZIF-8@AZO (0.64 mA, −0.53 V) and AZO (0.34 mA, −0.48 V) at 5 mV s–1, demonstrating the superior catalytic activity of Co-NC@AZO. This can be further verified by the Tafel plots shown in the inset of b, in which Co-NC@AZO has a lower slope of 20 mV dec–1 compared with those for ZIF-8@AZO (27 mV dec–1) and AZO (39 mV dec–1), indicating the fast oxidization reactions of Li2S on the Co-NC@AZO surface. To further reveal the catalytic activity of Co-NC@AZO toward LiPS conversion from the theoretical perspective, DFT calculations were conducted by considering the decomposition ability of Li2S on catalytically active surfaces. c and S23 show the Li2S decomposition pathways on the Co (1 1 1) and Co–4N–C surface models. The results show that the decomposition energy barrier of Li2S on Co (1 1 1) is as small as 0.17 eV, which ensures the effective catalytic decomposition of Li2S. Besides, a rapid reduction reaction from LiPS to Li2S is also critical for an efficient LiPS conversion process. Therefore, the liquid–solid conversion process of LiPS was tested by nucleation and growth experiments of Li2S to inspect the reduction kinetics of different electrodes. As given in d–f, Co-NC@AZO exhibits the highest capacity and earliest responsivity (345.66 mA h g–1, 1170 s) of Li2S nucleation compared with ZIF-8@AZO (245.25 mA h g–1, 1222 s) and AZO (171.33 mA h g–1, 1369 s), confirming the high capability and rapid nucleation kinetics of Li2S, which contributes to the fast and efficient electrochemistry of the Co-NC@AZO sulfur host.

Flexible and foldable pouch cells with the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode were further explored. Based on the schematic illustration (a), a large-area (3 × 4 cm2) pouch cell with high S loading (4 mg cm–2) was fabricated, and the corresponding E/S ratio was 5.2 μL mg–1. Experimentally, an open-circuit voltage (OCV) of 2.66 V was achieved by the Li–S pouch cell. It can successfully power a red light-emitting diode (LED) as shown in b. Moreover, the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode has the ability to illuminate LED badges under various bending conditions (c). No apparent change in the LED brightness can be observed during the bending and folding process. Also, even when flattening and folding again, the series resistance remains unchanged and the R ct is only slightly increased, convincingly verifying the high flexibility and robustness of the Co-NC@AZO-based pouch cell. In addition, outstanding performance in cycling stability is also observed in the Co-NC@AZO/S-based pouch cell, which liberates a satisfactory specific capacity of 897.5 mA h g–1 under 0.1 C after 100 cycles. The superior stability of the pouch cell is mainly due to the excellent trapping capacity of sulfur species by the designed Co-NC@AZO cathode: the macro-/microporous multistage architecture provides a mass of adsorption sites for LiPS; the strong polar adsorption for LiPS by AZO and Co-NC suppresses the shuttle effect; the catalytic effect of Co-NC significantly enhances the electrochemical redox kinetics of LiPS (d). The reduced polysulfide dissolution limits the decreased ionic conductivity, rapid lithium metal anode corrosion, premature precipitation of LiPS in the electrolyte, and the accompanying sulfur loss, which are considered as the main reasons for pouch cell failure. As a result, the design of multifunctional Co-NC@AZO electrodes is of significant potential for practical electronics and portable storage applications. In the future work, the production of Li–S pouch cells with high specific energy and long cycle life is a subject for new ideas related to materials, electrode structures, and electrolytes.

cln_elements.content: In summary, a hierarchical structure consisting of AZO as the conductive ordered macroporous framework and embedded Co-NC as the microporous catalytic nanoparticles is rationally designed and successfully prepared as an advanced sulfur immobilizer and catalytical promoter. The AZO material possesses both excellent polysulfide adsorption and good electronic conductivity, whereas the macroporous framework accelerates the mass transportation and electrolyte infiltration, simultaneously providing plentiful and accessible sites for strong LiPS adsorption. Meanwhile, micro-/mesoporous Co-NC is embedded in the macropores to further strengthen the LiPS adsorption as well as catalytically accelerate LiPS conversion kinetics at the same time. Attributed to the material and structural superiorities, the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode delivers a low capacity decay of 0.020% per cycle for 500 cycles at 1 C, exhibiting a notable rate capability of 635.5 mA h g–1 up to 5 C. Especially, at a S loading of 6.8 mg cm–2, a high areal capacity of 5.8 mA h cm–2 is achieved under lean electrolyte conditions (E/S = 5.7). With these benefits, the pouch cell based on the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode also provides excellent long-term stability of 897.5 mA h g–1 within 100 cycles at 0.1 C under 4 mg cm–2 sulfur loading. This work offers a strategy for a superior sulfur host with hierarchical architecture and multifunction to achieve effective anchoring and conversion of LiPS, holding great promises in practical application in Li–S batteries.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a hierarchical structure consisting of AZO as the conductive ordered macroporous framework and embedded Co-NC as the microporous catalytic nanoparticles is rationally designed and successfully prepared as an advanced sulfur immobilizer and catalytical promoter. The AZO material possesses both excellent polysulfide adsorption and good electronic conductivity, whereas the macroporous framework accelerates the mass transportation and electrolyte infiltration, simultaneously providing plentiful and accessible sites for strong LiPS adsorption. Meanwhile, micro-/mesoporous Co-NC is embedded in the macropores to further strengthen the LiPS adsorption as well as catalytically accelerate LiPS conversion kinetics at the same time. Attributed to the material and structural superiorities, the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode delivers a low capacity decay of 0.020% per cycle for 500 cycles at 1 C, exhibiting a notable rate capability of 635.5 mA h g-1 up to 5 C. Especially, at a S loading of 6.8 mg cm-2, a high areal capacity of 5.8 mA h cm-2 is achieved under lean electrolyte conditions (E/S = 5.7). With these benefits, the pouch cell based on the Co-NC@AZO/S cathode also provides excellent long-term stability of 897.5 mA h g-1 within 100 cycles at 0.1 C under 4 mg cm-2 sulfur loading. This work offers a strategy for a superior sulfur host with hierarchical architecture and multifunction to achieve effective anchoring and conversion of LiPS, holding great promises in practical application in Li-S batteries.

etc.condition: within 100 cycles at 0.1 C under 4 mg cm^–2 sulfur loading
